In 2016, after a pilgrimage to Medjugorje, Bosnia-Herzegovina, she reported that a statue of the Virgin Mary she brought back from there began shedding tears of blood. These events attracted pilgrims and led to monthly prayer meetings.
Cardia set up a foundation to collect donations, which she said would be used to build a centre for sick children.
In March 2024, Bishop Marco Salvi of the diocese of Civita Castellana declared that the alleged apparitions were "not supernatural", citing theological inconsistencies in the messages.
A private investigator found that the blood on the statue "came from a pig", triggering a judicial investigation.
In 2023, the prosecutor opened a fraud investigation against Cardia and ordered laboratory tests from a forensic geneticist.
These recent forensic analyses revealed that the blood on the statue matched Cardia's own DNA,…

As everyone has seen, participation in the Angelus prayer has decreased significantly during the pontificate of Francis. Epistles.online published statistics (February 8). During the last years of John …עוד
During the last years of John Paul II (2000-2005), participation in the Angelus remained high, with an estimated 40,000 to 50,000 people.
The Jubilee of 2000 and the frequent canonizations also contributed to an increased number of pilgrims in Rome.
Under Benedict XVI, Angelus attendance remained respectable, but lower than in the peak years of John Paul II. It averaged between 15,000 and 30,000 per week.
By 2011 and 2012, attendance had declined further, with estimates ranging from 10,000 to 20,000 per Angelus.
Benedict's last Angelus in 2013 drew an enormous crowd, with more than 50,000 in attendance.
Francis' election in March 2013 initially sparked enthusiasm. His first Angelus drew huge crowds, with 60,000 in attendance.
